title: As a fellow girl gamer, it's not fair that the majority of the female champions are
body: ranged. Go. Go ahead and check all the champs on client and count them. The majority are ranged. The majority of male champs are also melee. Are you freaking kidding me riot. Females should not be thought of as the "weak" gender and have to do things in combat from damn distance. Males shouldn't be the only ones spraying their testosterone against other "close quarter combat" male melees spraying their own testosterone. Only 13/40 female champs are melee. It's disgustingly bias and I have no words to say to you Riot.

Wow. Where to begin...

1. **Your first problem is the assertion that 'ranged' is synonymous with 'weak'. **That's a perception problem on your part, not anyone else's. 
2. **Your second problem--also one of perception--is the math.** 13/40 is about 33%. One third. ONE THIRD. Consider that the same percentage of all champions are also female. Somehow in your righteousness you seem to leave that out. Entirely.
3. **Your entire premise, as is typical of these types of arguments, offers no solutions.** What niche do you think another melee champion could fill that hasn't already been filled? There's 120 champions. If you're proactive enough to come up with this... enlightening critique of champion diversity, you would be better served by actually articulating what you think that diversity should look like.
4. **That poll... that poll.** It's amazingly immature, and identifying oneself as a 'girl gamer' generally is a red flag; by some grand stretch of the imagination, you seem to be under the impression that your clear bias is somehow more noteworthy than other biases--even the imaginary ones you put forth in your post. 

Would it be cool to see female melee champions? Sure. This particular argument and the way it's presented though? Nah.

I'd like to offer a different perspective on this issue. When I read your argument the first thing that I wanted to check is whether we were mainly relegating female Champions to mystical waif roles instead of letting them kick ass in battle in any way a player would like. I assigned a gender and a main role to each Champion for this purpose—the roles are something I assigned on my own and don't represent how our design team sees them—counting all monsters (Cho'Gath, Vel'Koz, Kog'Maw, etc.) as male because we use the 'he' pronoun to refer to them.

* Out of a total of 120 Champions, 40 (33.3%) are female.
* For Assassins, 3 out of 9 (33.3%) Champions are female (Akali, Katarina, LeBlanc).
* For Fighters, 11 out of 33 (33.3%) Champions are female (Diana, Elise, Evelynn, Fiora, Irelia, Kayle, Nidalee, Poppy, Riven, Shyvana, Vi).
* For Mages, 10 out of 32 (31.3%) Champions are female (Ahri, Anivia, Annie, Cassiopeia, Karma, Lissandra, Lulu, Lux, Orianna, Syndra).
* For Marksmen, 8 out of 17 (47.1%) Champions are female (Ashe, Caitlyn, Jinx, Miss Fortune, Quinn, Sivir, Tristana, Vayne).
* For Supports, 6 out of 10 (60.0%) Champions are female (Janna, Morgana, Nami, Sona, Soraka, Zyra).
* For Tanks, 2 out of 19 (10.5%) Champions are female (Leona, Sejuani).

The numbers for most of the roles look fairly distributed. What jumps out are Support, where female Champions are over-represented, and Tanks, where they're under-represented. We can definitely improve in having more tough, resilient female Champions—and female monsters, too!

However, even if we fall a little short in this area we do aim to make all Champions feel badass. We view female Champions with the same respect, and aim to grant them the same narrative agency and importance, that we do male Champions. Our focus—which I believe is more important than the raw population numbers—is having a variety of strong, independent women who have stories of their own going on and don't need anyone to rescue them. We want you to feel like you're this invulnerable bastion locking the enemy down and keeping your team safe when you play Leona, and we want to make you feel like your punches are ridiculously powerful and satisfying when you play Vi. Hopefully if the play experience and fantasy are good enough you will be able to feel like there are strong women that can genuinely represent you and have a good time, even if we fall short on perfect parity.

As an aside, Cedriel, this may be a troll thread but I appreciate your response all the same. The issue it raises does exist and I'm comforted that Riot is aware of it, and that you're above the ridiculous slew of misinformation and hate that the community has about feminism.

There have been a number of interesting studies around how people perceive equality. The most striking result has been that people view a group as having "balanced" gender representation if there are only 17% women. Given that women make up ~50% of the general population, that's a huge gap between what we see as balanced and what *actual* balance looks like from an objective, numbers-driven perspective.

With that in mind, it's not entirely surprising that you'd look at those stats and conclude that champion representation is relatively balanced, with only supports and tanks as outliers. But I'd encourage you to look again: Marksmen are the *only* class that has anything like a balanced representation. Actually, Supports are *less* skewed than (+10%) than the total numbers or the Assassin/Fighter/Mage numbers (-17%).

So I'd look at the same numbers and come to a completely different conclusion, namely that there are only two classes where the numbers *aren't* screwed up: Marksmen and Supports. (Though I think we can all agree that Tanks are the most unbalanced class and that development of new female Tanks should probably be given priority at some point.)

So, I'm the type of person who primarily plays female characters across different games (e.g., my WOW characters are almost entirely female). For any role I want to play in League of Legends, I can actually find a decent female champion that works for me. I can actually avoid male champions if I want, and I appreciate that I can make that choice. In every role, there are at least two possibilities for me to choose from, and I do appreciate that much.

However, the relative balance of females as characters in games like League of Legends should ultimately come down to how much people want to play them and choose to play them. If you make 20 or 30 female characters no one plays, then having equal numbers of male and female options becomes actually a false choice (and would ultimately hurt women players by actually having weak female champions that were avoided). So, on-paper representation of equality has to mean more than just having % values coming out to be equal for male and female characters. What should also matter is how much people play them in practice (and understanding if increasing availability would increase frequency of people playing female champions, or whether more female champions would attract more female players), and how well those champions are designed.

If League of Legend has somewhere around a 10 to 20% female player base (estimated example), then having 33% of the characters be female is actually relatively representative of the League of Legends population (even if it doesn't reflect the population of the world at large. So, for figuring out representation of women characters for league of legends, 33% may just end up being more sustainable in the short-term, if people just simply want to play male characters more than female characters. What gender people want to play is ultimately a question Riot could answer with data of their own, and what gender people want to play ends up having to shape the game design in some way. In the end, it is really a complicated problem of what a target representation number should be.

Females (human) naturally have less muscle mass than males, so even **if** female champions were portrayed to be weak on purpose there is a very good reason for it. While the average female has less muscle mass than the average male, the distributions are still largely overlapping. There are some females who have larger muscle mass than some males (the female bodybuilders can do amazingly impressive things). So, in a video game, where characters are animated, there is no biological reason why we couldn't have some females being more muscular and less skinny. It looks like the female tank role in particular is really the only one underrepresented (with the other roles having a reasonably large representation of female characters). Thus, having one or two more female tanks in the future wouldn't be a bad idea, but not for the sake of representation - but because that means there are likely more untapped character concepts in that role that could end up being really neat.

I agree wholly with your point about tapping interesting archetypes and concepts. Imagine for example a large, motherly character, a tank or tanky support, who is literally taking care of the other champions. In fact I could imagine Braum being done this way in an alternate universe (though I would miss the moustache).

I think it is worth pointing out that a lot of league's design is drawn from archetypes and tropes meaning that characters are developed which match things we expect to see in a fantasy world. Leona is very similar to a Valkyrie for example and Karthus is very much a Lich, Ahri does double duty as a Kitsune from Japanese myth and the more general trope of a seductress. This means that tropes that wildly differ from what we expect from both the real world and fantasy (for example, a female executioner with a muscular build who would satisfy the tropes Darius currently fills) are less likely to show up (not that I would mind, that concept could be incredibly cool) because it resonates less with what we, the audience, know. We are less likely to say "oh, I get that, that's cool" and more likely to just tilt our heads and say "what's this supposed to be?"

One way to circumvent this is to tie the character to some other aspect which is gender neutral. For example, women can be mothers, and seductresses, and Valkyries, or they can be more gender neutral things like psychopaths and punk rock powerhouse punching persons (okay, I went overboard with the alliteration there). Jinx and Vi actually do this very well. Though they are female, their defining characteristics are tied to gender neutral tropes, Jinx is a psychopath/supervillain (like the joker) and Vi's character is tied very much to her steampunk and punk rock aesthetics.

TLDR: It's not all Riot's fault for using female archetypes and non-burly women can still be defined by things other than their gender

I actually think having 50% female champions really isn't a realistic goal worth asking for, because it may not actually reflect the demographics of characters that would be relatable to people. It is still possible to ask for more creativity and innovation if there is evidence that a company is taking the easy route to designing characters at some point along the way. Non-stereotypical characters (e.g., muscular women whose boobs are covered) might make interesting contrast if that is a character model type that isn't well represented. If done well, counter-stereotypical examples can potentially stand out and become popular if they resonate with enough people and are done well.
